conversation.content: So tell me about your experience as a silversmith.

Well, I've been working with silver for, um, about twelve years now, and honestly, I started out making maybe twenty pieces a month but now I'm producing around eighty to ninety custom pieces monthly.
That's quite an increase in production.
Oh absolutely, I mean, when I opened my first studio in 2015, er, I was charging maybe $45 per piece, but you know, now my average commission runs between $350 and $1,200 depending on complexity.
How many employees do you [pause] currently manage?
Right now I have a team of six artisans working under me, and we handle about 300 client orders quarterly, which keeps us all pretty busy but not overwhelmed.
So, what's your, uhh, typical profit margin, I guess, on these pieces?
Most silver jewelry runs about a 60% profit margin after materials and labor, though custom wedding bands can go up to 75% because clients value that personal touch.
What about material costs?
Silver's trading at around $24 per ounce right now, and a typical ring uses maybe 0.3 ounces, so material cost is only $7-8 but the real value comes from the craftsmanship.
How long does it take to complete a piece?
Well, a simple band takes, hmm, maybe three hours, but actually, complex designs with stones, you know, can take fifteen to twenty hours spread over several days.
What's your most expensive creation?
Oh that would be, er, a $12,000 [sarcastic] "simple" tea set that took me, basically, four months to complete because the client kept changing their mind about the engravings.
Four months sounds, um, [cry loudly] exhausting, I mean, how did you manage that?
Honestly, I broke it down into, like, weekly milestones and charged them, uhh, an extra 30% for revisions, so it ended up being quite profitable despite the headaches.
Right so, what percentage of your business is, err, custom work versus, you know, ready-made pieces?
About 70% custom and 30% [hesitantly] ready-made, though I'm trying to shift that to 50-50 because the ready-made pieces have better margins and less client drama.
Hmm, how many pieces do you, actually, keep in inventory, sort of, at any given time?
Usually around, well, 150 to 200 pieces worth maybe, uh, $40,000 total, though honestly, during holiday season I'll stock up to 300 pieces because December accounts for 35% of annual sales.
